Understand what an automorphic number is: a number whose square ends in the same digits as the number itself.
Define the range for three-digit numbers, which is from 100 to 999.
Determine the condition that the last three digits of the square of a number (n^2) should be identical to the number itself (n).
Compute the last three digits of n^2 for each number n, from 100 to 999.
Check each result to see if it ends with the original number n.
List all numbers for which the condition is satisfied to identify all three-digit automorphic numbers.
